abstract: The microblogging network, which is primarily geared to public messages, is making it easier for its 288 million users to send private messages to each other.
snippet: The microblogging network, which is primarily geared to public messages, is making it easier for its 288 million users to send private messages to each other.
lead_paragraph: Twitter announced Monday that its users will be able to change a setting on their accounts to allow anyone to send them a private message. In addition, if a person follows a big account — for example, from a company like United Airlines — the Twitter user can respond to messages sent by that account even if the account, United in this case, does not follow that individual.
